title: 106_s2821
content: The Act may be cited as the "FERS Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation Buyback Act of 2000". It addresses the creditability of service. The "FERS Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation Buyback Act of 2000" amends Section 8411(b) of title 5, United States Code to include service as a temporary or intermittent employee for the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation between December 31, 1988, and June 30, 2000, of at least 1 year's duration for credit purposes under this chapter. An employee or Member must deposit 1.3 percent of basic pay for service as a temporary or intermittent employee for the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation between December 31, 1988, and June 30, 2000, to receive credit under this chapter. The deposit must be made within 5 years of October 1, 2000, or the date the employee or Member first returns to service after the temporary period. The deposit for service as a temporary or intermittent employee must be made within 5 years to receive credit. Interest is included and compounded annually if the deposit is not made in full. Service will be creditable, but annuity may be reduced if the deposit is not made or is incomplete. PROVISIONS RELATING TO PERSONS WHO HAVE SEPARATED. The Office of Personnel Management will prescribe regulations for obtaining credit for service performed by individuals who have separated from Government service. Credit will only be given upon submission of a written application by December 31, 2001. Any annuity or survivor annuity will be recomputed to include the service described in the regulations. The Office of Personnel Management will prescribe regulations for obtaining credit for service performed by individuals who have separated from Government service. An annuity will be recomputed to include the service described in the regulations, effective for amounts accruing more than 30 days after the application is submitted. If the full deposit required is not timely made, a reduction will be made in the recomputed annuity. Interest is not included in the deposit. The Office of Personnel Management will notify individuals of their rights under the Act and assist in obtaining necessary information from the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation. The Corporation must provide information on an individual's service upon request from the Office.
